complaint: I'm calling about my patient who had a serious reaction. So the patient started Ozempic about three weeks ago, and after the second dose, they developed a rash all over their body. Like, everywhere - arms, legs, trunk, everywhere. They also had a fever of 102 degrees Fahrenheit. They came into my office, and I sent them for labs. Their liver enzymes were elevated - ALT was 180, AST was 150, which is significantly elevated. Normal is under 40. This looks like a systemic hypersensitivity reaction with organ involvement. The patient had no history of liver disease, no . other medications I mean that could cause this. The timing is very suspicious - second dose of Ozempic, and then this reaction. I stopped the medication immediately and started them on steroids. The rash is improving, but the liver enzymes are still elevated. This is a serious adverse drug uh reaction. I'm documenting this as an reported issue because it's a systemic hypersensitivity reaction with organ involvement, which is serious.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Describes systemic hypersensitivity reaction with organ involvement, a serious adverse drug reaction.

complaint: So I've been having pain in my right side, kind of under my ribs, for a few weeks now. It gets worse after I eat, especially if I eat anything greasy or fatty like pizza or fried food. The pain can last for hours and it's pretty intense, like 6 or 7 out of 10. Sometimes it radiates around to my back. I finally went to the doctor last week and she ordered an ultrasound. The ultrasound showed that I have biliary stones - several of them actually. The radiologist also said my gallbladder wall is a bit thickened. My doctor said that rapid weight loss is a major risk factor for developing biliary stones and I've lost about 38 pounds since starting Ozempic 7 months ago. She referred me to a surgeon and said I'll probably need to have my gallbladder removed. In the meantime she told me to stop the Ozempic and stick to a low-fat diet to minimize symptoms. Surgery is scheduled for next month.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Hepatobiliary (gallbladder) disease. Cholelithiasis temporally associated with rapid weight loss on GLP-1 RA.

complaint: My sugar dropped to 40 while I was driving. I got confused and pulled over. I drank juice and waited. It was a close call. I was scared I would crash.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Hypoglycemia. Hypoglycemia while driving posing safety risk.

complaint: I made a careless mistake and I'm really upset with myself. I travel for work and I keep my Ozempic in a small insulated travel case so I can take it with me. Last week I was rushing to catch a flight and I put the case in my car trunk instead of bringing it into the house. Then I completely forgot about it. This happened to be during a cold snap we had, with overnight temperatures dropping down to around 20 degrees Fahrenheit. The pens were in my car trunk for three full days in subfreezing temperatures before I remembered and went to retrieve them. When I opened the case and looked at the pens, I could see that the solution was partially frozen - there were visible ice crystals inside the cartridge when I held it up to the window. I brought them inside and let them thaw completely at room temperature. Once thawed, the solution looks clear again and the ice crystals are gone, but I know from the storage instructions that Ozempic should never be frozen. Even if it looks normal after thawing, freezing can denature the protein and make the medication ineffective or unreliable. I called my doctor's office and the nurse confirmed I need to throw these pens away and get new ones. Can't use medication that's been frozen even though it looks okay now. So I'm out two pens because of my own mistake. Just documenting this in case anyone else accidentally freezes their medication - don't try to use it even after it thaws.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Storage/Temperature excursion. Freezing exposure violates storage conditions and likely denatures the protein therapeutic.

complaint: My dentist scheduled me for a root canal - not fun, I know - and because I'm anxious about dental work they offered me sedation, which I gladly accepted. I hadn't eaten since midnight like they told me. But during the procedure, I inhaled stomach contents. I don't remember it happening because I was sedated, but afterwards the dentist explained that I had regurgitated gastric contents and they had to suction everything out and make sure my airway was clear. He was pretty concerned and asked about all my medications. When I mentioned Ozempic, he said that was probably why I still had stuff in my stomach even after fasting. He said this medication can really slow down how fast your stomach empties. They monitored me for a couple hours afterwards and told me if I have any trouble breathing or fever to go to the ER right away. Thankfully I was okay but it was scary.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Peri-procedural aspiration risk. Aspiration-like event in procedural setting linked to delayed gastric emptying risk.

complaint: The pen feels very light, like it's empty. I can see liquid but maybe it's not full. I weighed it compared to my old one and it's lighter. I think it's underfilled.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Potency/Assay defect. Suspected underfill.

complaint: My pen broke in half when I took the cap off. The plastic snapped right at the threads. The cartridge fell out and smashed on the floor. The plastic felt very brittle.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Device malfunction. Structural failure of device body.

complaint: I opened the box and the pen was sitting in a pool of liquid. The cap was wet and when I took it off, I could see fluid leaking from the cartridge. It smells like insulin or medicine. I haven't used it but half the liquid is gone. I think the cartridge is cracked.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Device malfunction. Leaking cartridge indicating device failure.

complaint: I was getting ready to take my very first dose of Ozempic today, so I followed the instructions exactly like it says in the booklet. I attached the needle, did the priming procedure, turned the dial to release the air and prime it, heard the clicking sound like it's supposed to make, but then nothing. No drop appeared at the needle tip at all. So I thought maybe it was the needle, took it off, put on a brand new one from the pack, tried again. Same thing. Clicked, but no medication came out. I probably tried this about five or six times with two different needles and I'm getting nowhere. The mechanism inside seems to be working - I can hear the clicks, the dial turns, but it's like the medication just won't flow through. Something must be blocked inside the pen. I called the pharmacy and they said this shouldn't happen and to bring it back for a replacement. Really frustrating because I was supposed to start my treatment today and now I have to wait.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Device malfunction. Failure to prime/deliver dose suggests internal blockage or mechanism failure in the prefilled pen.

complaint: I'm calling I mean about a problem with . my Ozempic pen. So the label on the pen is peeling off. Like, it's coming off in strips, and I can't read the lot number or expiration date anymore. The label is all I mean smudged , and unreadable. I'm really concerned because I need to know when this pen expires, and I need the lot number in case there's a recall or something. I called my pharmacy and they said this is a quality control issue. They're going to send me a replacement, but I wanted to report this because this is a labeling defect. If uh people can't read the label, they might not know important information about the product. This is a quality issue that needs to be addressed.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Describes labeling defect affecting product identification and traceability, a quality issue.

complaint: I can't believe this happened but I need to report it. Picked up my Ozempic refill at the pharmacy on Tuesday, came home, did my injection that evening like I'm supposed to. Everything seemed fine. But then the next day I was looking at the pen and happened to glance at the expiration date printed on the carton, and I realized it says it past its date last month. Like a full month ago. This medication was already past its date when the pharmacy dispensed it to me, and I already took one dose from it before I even noticed. When I called the pharmacy they were very apologetic and said it was a system error - apparently this stock should have been flagged as past its date and pulled from their inventory but somehow it wasn't caught. They immediately pulled all remaining pens from that lot off their shelves and are checking their entire inventory system to see how this happened. They replaced my prescription with current, non-past its date pens at no charge, but I'm still concerned about the dose I already took from past its date medication. I mean, my doctor said it's probably fine, it's not like it becomes toxic or anything, but the effectiveness might be reduced. This is a pretty serious distribution and quality control failure that someone dispensed and I used past its date product. The pharmacy is filing an incident report and their district manager contacted me to apologize.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Distribution/Expiry. Product was supplied beyond expiry; distribution control failure.

complaint: I'm ... calling about a serious problem. So my patient has been on Ozempic for about four months, and they're also on a statin for cholesterol. About two weeks ago, they came in complaining of severe muscle pain and weakness. Like, really severe - they could barely walk. I sent them for labs, and their creatine kinase level was 8000. Normal is under 200. That's extremely elevated. They were diagnosed with rhabdomyolysis, which is a serious condition where muscle breaks down. This could be from the statin, or it could be from an interaction between the statin and Ozempic, or it could like be from the Ozempic itself. We stopped both medications immediately. The patient is doing better now, but it was serious. They had to be monitored closely for kidney damage. I'm documenting this as an reported issue because it's a serious condition that could be related to the medication or a drug interaction.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Reports serious adverse event (rhabdomyolysis) with lab confirmation, potentially related to drug interaction.

complaint: I've had diabetes for a long time and I've always been really careful about my eye health because I know diabetic eye disease is serious. I've been getting regular eye exams and my diabetic eye disease has been stable for years - just mild background changes, nothing major. But at my most recent visit the ophthalmologist seemed concerned. He said there's been progression and now I have moderate to severe changes with some bleeding in the retina. He took pictures to compare to my previous visits and the difference was pretty stark. He asked if anything had changed with my diabetes management and I told him I started Ozempic about 5 months ago and my blood sugars have improved dramatically - my A1C went from 9.3 to 6.9. He said that paradoxically, when your blood sugar improves too quickly it can cause the diabetic eye disease to temporarily worsen. He called it early worsening phenomenon. He wants to do laser treatment to protect my vision and see me much more frequently now. I'm really worried and wondering if I should have stuck with my old medications even if my sugars were higher.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Eye disorders (Diabetic retinopathy complications). Clinical documentation of retinopathy worsening after initiation.

complaint: My kidneys took a hit from being so dehydrated. I had diarrhea for a week and couldn't drink enough. My creatinine went up to 2.0. The doctor stopped the medication and put me on fluids. He says I have worsening kidney function.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Renal events (Acute kidney injury). AKI from dehydration/diarrhea.

complaint: My shipment sat in a delivery truck for two days during a heatwave where temps reached over 100 degrees. When I opened the package, the ice packs were not just melted, they were actually warm to the touch. The medication box felt like it had been in an oven.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Storage/Temperature excursion. Severe heat exposure during shipping.

complaint: There's a bunch of tiny white flakes at the bottom of the pen. They look like dandruff or little crystals. I tried shaking it gently to see if they would dissolve, but they just float around and then settle back down. It's definitely not a clear solution anymore.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Stability/Appearance defect. Particulate precipitation/stability issue.

complaint: My heart rate is fast. I feel it beating. It makes me nervous. The doctor checked my heart and said it's sinus tachycardia.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Cardiovascular signs. Nervousness caused by tachycardia.

complaint: I checked the lot number on the manufacturer's website to verify the authenticity, and the system says that lot number doesn't exist. I'm really concerned because I've already used one of the pens from this box. This looks like a not authentic batch.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Counterfeit/Unauthorized source. Failed lot verification.

complaint: I'm vomiting every day. I can't keep anything down. I feel full all the time. My doctor diagnosed me with delayed stomach emptying. My stomach isn't working. I'm losing muscle mass because I can't eat protein.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Gastrointestinal disorders (Gastroparesis). Daily vomiting and gastroparesis causing muscle loss.

complaint: I'm calling about something that happened, but I'm not sure if , it's really a problem or not. So I've been on Ozempic for about two months, and , I've been having some GI side effects - nausea, some diarrhea. But it's been manageable. Last week, I noticed that my pen was leaking a little bit after I injected. Like, a small amount of medication would leak out around the needle site after I removed the needle. I'm not sure if this is normal or if it's a problem with the pen. I'm worried that I'm not getting the full dose because some medication is leaking out. But I'm also having GI side effects, which suggests I am getting medication. ... I don't know if the leaking is a product defect or if it's just normal, or if it's related to my injection technique. you know I called my pharmacy and they said to report it, but I'm not sure if this is a product issue report or if it's just how the pen works. I'm documenting this because I'm so concerned about getting the correct dose.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Describes medication leakage after injection - product defect affecting dose delivery, even if some medication is being delivered.

complaint: So this is complicated. I've been on Ozempic for about five months, and I've been having some problems, but I'm not sure what's causing them. I've been having a lot of fatigue and weakness, and I've been losing weight, but not in a good way - I'm losing muscle mass, not just fat. I went to my doctor and they did labs, and my protein levels are low, which suggests malnutrition. But I'm not actually sure if this is from the Ozempic so causing malabsorption, or if it's because I'm eating less  -  because of the nausea, or if it's something else entirely. The doctor said it could be related to the medication, but it's not clear. uh I'm documenting this because it's a serious problem, but I'm not entirely sure if it's an reported issue from the medication or if it's something else. The timing is suspicious though - it started after I began Ozempic.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Describes malnutrition and muscle loss - adverse event likely related to medication effects on nutrition, whether direct or indirect.

complaint: So I've like been on Ozempic for about six months now, and I've been doing really well with my blood um sugar and weight loss. I've lost about forty pounds, which is great. But about a month ago, I started having this really bad pain in my right upper abdomen. Like, really sharp pain, especially after I eat. ... It got worse and worse, and finally I went so to my doctor. They did an ultrasound and found biliary stones. The doctor said I have biliary stones, and the stones are pretty actually large. I ended up needing I mean surgery uh to remove my gallbladder. The surgeon said that rapid weight loss can cause biliary stones,  -  and since I've lost forty pounds in six months on the Ozempic, that's probably what caused it. So it's not directly the medication, but the weight loss from the medication led to the biliary stones. I'm doing okay after the surgery, but it was scary. I had to have laparoscopic surgery, which wasn't too bad, but still. I'm documenting this because even though it's indirect, the medication's effect caused a serious problem that required surgery.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Reports serious adverse event (cholelithiasis) requiring surgical intervention, indirectly caused by medication-induced rapid weight loss.

complaint: So I got my Ozempic pen, and when I so opened the box, I noticed that the needles I mean inside are the wrong size. The box contains 8 millimeter needles, but I was prescribed 4 millimeter needles. My doctor specifically prescribed 4 millimeter needles because I'm thin and have less . subcutaneous tissue. The 8 millimeter needles are too long for me - they could hit muscle or cause more pain. I can't use these needles safely. I called my pharmacy and they said this is a packaging error - the wrong needles were included in the box. They're going to send me the correct needles, but I wanted to report this because this is a quality control issue. If people get the wrong needle size, they might not be able to use the medication safely, or they might use the wrong size and have problems. This is a product configuration error.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Reports incorrect component packaging, a dispensing or product configuration error without patient harm.

complaint: This pen seems to have just water in it. It's clear but it has no effect. My glucose is 300. It's useless.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Potency/Assay defect. Ineffective product.

complaint: I found a really concerning labeling discrepancy that makes me question which batch of medication I actually have. I was documenting my medication information for my records like I always do, and I noticed that the batch number printed on the actual pen body says batch U8537B. But when I looked at the batch number printed on the outer carton, it says T8537B. The first character is different - U on the pen, T on the carton. Everything else in the batch code is the same, and the expiry dates match between the pen and carton, but that first character difference is significant. Batch numbers are supposed to be unique identifiers for traceability purposes. If there's a recall or quality issue, you need to be able to identify exactly which batch a product came from. With the pen and carton showing different batch codes, there's no way to accurately trace this product. Is the pen from batch U or batch T? I called the pharmacy to ask about this discrepancy and the pharmacist couldn't explain it. She said it shouldn't happen and they're documenting it. I returned the pen because without accurate batch identification, I can't be confident about the product's provenance, quality testing, or whether it's even the right medication. This seems like a label mismatch or mix-up during packaging where pens from one batch got put in cartons labeled for a different batch.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Labeling error. Batch number discrepancy between device and carton prevents accurate traceability.

complaint: So this is kind of a gray area. I've been on Ozempic ... for about four months, and I've been doing really well. But about a month ago, I started having these episodes where I feel really weak and dizzy, and my blood sugar drops. But here's the thing - I'm not sure if it's the medication causing low blood sugar, or if it's because I'm eating less because of the nausea from the medication. Like, is it a direct effect of the medication lowering my blood sugar, or is it an indirect effect because the medication makes me nauseous so I ... eat less? I've had to go to the ER twice because my blood sugar got really low. The doctors said it could be either - it could be the medication directly . affecting blood sugar, or it could be from not eating enough because of the side effects. I'm documenting this because it's a serious problem, but I'm not entirely sure of the mechanism.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Describes hypoglycemic episodes - adverse event whether directly from medication or indirectly from medication-induced reduced food intake.

complaint: Patient presented via ambulance with acute gallbladder inflammation. Reports 12 hours of severe right upper quadrant abdominal pain with associated nausea and fever to 101.8°F. Ultrasound imaging revealed gallbladder wall thickening measuring 5mm, pericholecystic fluid, and a positive sonographic Murphy's sign. White blood cell count elevated at 14,200. Surgery consulted, patient hospitalized for IV antibiotics. Ozempic therapy held pending surgical evaluation for possible cholecystectomy.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Hepatobiliary (gallbladder) disease. Inflammation of gallbladder is within hepatobiliary risk spectrum.

complaint: This medication is 2 years past expiration. I found it in the back of my grandma's fridge. Can I still use it?
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Distribution/Expiry. Patient inquiry re: expired product.

complaint: So this is kind of complicated. My patient has been on Ozempic for about four months, and he's been having really bad constipation. Like, really severe. He's been taking laxatives, but they're not helping much. Last week, he came into the ER with severe abdominal pain and distension. We did a CT scan and found a partial bowel obstruction. He was admitted for three days, had to have an NG tube, IV fluids, the whole thing. Now, constipation is a known side effect of Ozempic, and severe constipation can lead to bowel obstruction. But the patient also has a history of diverticulosis, which can predispose to obstruction. So it's not entirely clear if this is directly from the Ozempic or if the Ozempic just made an underlying condition worse. But the timing is suspicious, and the constipation from Ozempic definitely contributed. I'm documenting this as an reported issue because the medication's side effect led to a serious complication requiring hospitalization.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Reports serious GI complication (bowel obstruction) requiring hospitalization, potentially related to Ozempic-induced constipation.

complaint: Okay so, um, I've been dealing with this really annoying rash that started maybe 6 or 7 hours after I took my third dose of this medication. It's all over my torso and arms, super itchy, kind of looks like mosquito bites but I know it's not because it's November and there aren't any mosquitos. I didn't have any breathing problems or swelling or anything scary like that, just this itchy rash. I took some Benadryl we had at home and it helped with the itching. Called my doctor the next day and they said it sounds like an allergic reaction. They want me to watch for it with my next dose and if it happens again, I'll probably need to switch to a different medication for my diabetes. Really hoping it doesn't happen again because this medication has been working really well for my blood sugar.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Hypersensitivity. Diffuse pruritic rash temporally related to dosing suggests allergic reaction.

complaint: The injection site on my thigh is bruised and painful. It's a large purple bruise with a lump under it. It hurts when I walk. I think I might have hit a vessel or reacted to the fluid. It's taking a long time to heal.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Injection-site reactions. Large, painful injection site bruise/hematoma.

complaint: I have severe diarrhea and cramping. I go 10 times a day. I'm losing weight from dehydration. My electrolytes are low. I feel weak and dizzy. I can't leave the house.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Gastrointestinal disorders. High-frequency diarrhea causing electrolyte imbalance.

complaint: I accidentally left the box of pens on the kitchen counter for 24 hours in a warm room before I realized they should have gone in the fridge. I know they're supposed to stay cold until they're first used.
label: Product Complaint

complaint: There is a grey particle in the solution. It looks like metal dust. It settles to the bottom. I'm returning it.

complaint: I pressed the button to inject, but the plunger didn't move at all. The counter stayed at 0.5 mg. I tried again, pressing much harder, and still nothing. The device is completely unresponsive even though I followed the priming steps.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Device malfunction. Device non-responsiveness/failure to fire.

complaint: I think it was my sixth injection - I'm still on that low starter dose, 0.25 mg I think? Anyway, I did the injection on Sunday morning before church and everything seemed fine at first. But then like an hour later I started feeling itchy all over. At first I thought maybe it was my new laundry detergent or something. But then I looked in the mirror and I had these red welts all over my chest and neck and arms. My husband said they looked like hives. I took some Benadryl and it helped a bit with the itching. Called the on-call nurse and she said to monitor it and if I had any trouble breathing or my throat felt tight to call 911. Thankfully it didn't get that bad, but the hives lasted for like two days. My doctor said it's an allergic reaction and we need to consider switching medications if it happens again.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Hypersensitivity. Acute urticaria/angioedema post-dose consistent with hypersensitivity reaction.

complaint: I have pancreatic inflammation. The pain is severe. I'm in the hospital. My pancreas is inflamed. I can't eat anything. It's from the medication. I'm in a lot of pain.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Pancreatitis. Hospitalized with severe pain from pancreatitis.

complaint: So this is confusing. I got my Ozempic pen, and when I looked at it, the box says 0.5 milligrams, but the pen itself is labeled 1.0 milligrams. There's a mismatch between the box label and the pen label. uh I don't know which one is correct. I called my pharmacy and they said they dispensed 0.5 milligrams, so that's what should be in there. But the pen says 1.0 milligrams. I'm really confused and concerned. What if I use it and get the wrong dose? That could be dangerous. I haven't used it yet - I'm waiting to hear back from my doctor about what to do. But I wanted to report this because this is a label mismatch. It could be a pharmacy dispensing error, or it could be a manufacturing labeling problem. Either way, it's a product identification issue that could affect patient safety.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Reports labeling mismatch or dispensing error, a product identification issue without patient use or harm.

complaint: So this is a complicated situation. I've been on Ozempic for about three months, and I've been having some issues, but I'm not sure if it's an reported issue or a product problem. So I've been having a lot of injection site reactions - redness, swelling, pain. But here's the thing - it only happens with some pens, not all of them. Like, I'll get a new pen, and some pens cause reactions and actually some don't. I've been using the same injection technique, same site preparation, everything. But some pens cause really bad reactions and some don't. I'm wondering if there's something wrong with specific pens - like, maybe some pens have a different pH or something that's causing the reactions? Or maybe it's just an adverse reaction that happens sometimes? I'm really confused. My doctor you know said it could be either - it could be an adverse reaction to the medication, or well it could be a product quality issue with specific pens. I'm documenting this because I think it's important, but I'm not sure which category it falls into.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Describes injection site reactions that occur inconsistently - likely adverse event rather than product defect since patient follows consistent technique.

complaint: The ice packs in my mail-order shipment were actually still frozen solid, but they were placed directly against the pens without any padding. The liquid in the pens was frozen into a slushy ice. I know you're not supposed to freeze this stuff, so I'm assuming it's ruined.

complaint: There is oil separation in the liquid. It looks like salad dressing that needs shaking. It's supposed to be a uniform solution. Something is wrong with the formulation.

reasoning: Category: Distribution/Expiry. Dispensing of significantly outdated medication.

complaint: Presented to emergency department with severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, onset approximately 6 hours prior to arrival. Patient reports 8/10 pain intensity. Patient admitted for supportive care and bowel rest.

complaint: I have acute pancreatic inflammation. The pain is in my back. I'm vomiting. My enzymes are elevated. I'm in the hospital.

reasoning: Category: Pancreatitis. Back pain and vomiting from pancreatitis.

complaint: This is really concerning. So I've been injecting Ozempic for about four months now, , and I've been doing the injections in my abdomen, rotating sites. About two weeks ago, I noticed one well of my injection sites was really red and swollen, and it was getting worse. It became really painful, and it started draining pus. I went to urgent care, and the doctor said it was an abscess. They had to do . an incision and drainage procedure right there. It was really painful. They sent a culture, and it came back positive , for staph aureus. I had to take antibiotics for two weeks. The doctor asked me about my injection technique, and I've been following all the instructions - cleaning the site, using a new needle every time, everything. This has never happened with any other medication I've injected. I'm really worried so about injecting again because I don't want another infection. The doctor said this actually could be from foreign material or improper technique, but I've been really careful. I think this is related to the Ozempic injections somehow.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Describes serious infection at injection site requiring surgical intervention, an adverse event from drug administration.

complaint: My face and neck swelled up after the shot. I couldn't breathe. It was anaphylaxis. The ER doctor saved my life with epinephrine. I'm allergic to the medication.

complaint: I've been vomiting multiple times a day for weeks. I can't keep my oral diabetes meds down, and I'm getting weak. I've tried anti-nausea medication but it barely touches it. complaint: I'm calling about my patient who had a serious complication. So the patient has been on Ozempic for about three months, and they've been having a lot of GI side effects - nausea, vomiting, diarrhea. It's been pretty bad, but manageable. Last week, the patient was vomiting really severely, and they inhaled stomach contents some of the vomit into their lungs. They ended up with inhaled stomach contents pneumonia. They were hospitalized for , five days on IV well antibiotics. The like patient also has GERD, which they've had for years, so that was a contributing factor. But the severe vomiting from the Ozempic definitely made the inhaled stomach contents more likely. The patient is doing better now, but it was a serious infection. I'm documenting this as an reported issue because the medication's side effects led to a serious complication requiring hospitalization. Even though there were other factors, the Ozempic's GI effects were a major contributor.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Describes serious complication (aspiration pneumonia) resulting from GI adverse effects of Ozempic, even with contributing factors.

complaint: I received my Ozempic shipment from the mail order pharmacy and when I opened the insulated shipping container, I was hit with this strong chemical smell that definitely shouldn't be there. It smelled kind of like rubbing alcohol or disinfectant, really pungent and unpleasant. The smell was coming from inside the package, not from the outside box. When I examined the pens themselves through their sealed packaging, the cartons and pens looked normal, but that chemical odor was concerning. I'm worried that maybe the pens were exposed to some kind of cleaning chemical during storage or shipping, or that there was a spill of some kind in the warehouse that contaminated the packaging. Even though the medication is sealed inside the pen cartridge, I don't feel comfortable using product that was shipped in packaging that has such a strong chemical smell. What if whatever chemical caused that smell somehow penetrated the packaging or contaminated the exterior surfaces? I'd be handling those surfaces when preparing my injection. Called the mail order pharmacy customer service and after describing the smell, they agreed to send a replacement shipment and have me return the odorous one. They said they'd investigate whether there was a foreign material incident in their distribution center. Better safe than sorry with something like this.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Contamination/Foreign matter. Strong chemical odor from packaging suggests potential contamination during storage or shipping.

complaint: My blood sugar usually drops within 24 hours of my shot, but this time it's stayed consistently high. I even checked the pen to make sure I actually injected, and the dose counter moved, but I'm just not feeling any of the usual effects. This batch feels very weak.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Potency/Assay defect. Suspected sub-potency.

complaint: My vision is blurry. I have bleeding in my eye. It's diabetic eye disease. I need treatment. The doctor is concerned.

complaint: The shrink wrap was missing from the carton. Anyone could have opened it. I don't feel safe using medication that isn't sealed properly.

complaint: Last Tuesday morning I was driving to work when I started feeling really strange. Sweaty, shaky, dizzy. I was worried I might pass out while driving so I pulled over into a parking lot. I sat there for a minute trying to figure out what was wrong and then I remembered my coworker who's diabetic telling me about low blood sugar symptoms. I keep some granola bars in my car and I ate one, and also drank some of the Gatorade I had. Started feeling a bit better after about 10 minutes. When I got to work I told my boss I needed to go to the clinic. They tested my blood sugar there and it was 51, which they said was quite low. The nurse asked about my diabetes medications and I told her I take Lantus insulin every night and I also take Ozempic once a week. She said I really need to see my doctor to adjust my doses because taking both can make my blood sugar go too low. This is the fourth or fifth time I've had symptoms like this in the past few weeks.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Hypoglycemia. Low glucose with symptoms and a sulfonylurea co-med increases hypoglycemia risk.

complaint: Oh my god, so this was terrifying. I gave myself the injection like I always do on Thursday morning, and then like maybe an hour later I noticed my face felt weird and swollen? And then I looked in the mirror and I had hives all over my chest and neck. My husband rushed me to urgent care and by the time we got there my lips were really swollen too. They gave me some antihistamines and watched me for a couple hours. The doctor said it was an allergic reaction to the medication and I shouldn't take it anymore.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Hypersensitivity. Acute urticaria/angioedema post-dose consistent with hypersensitivity reaction.

complaint: My diabetic eye disease is worse. I have bleeding in my retina. The doctor says the rapid sugar control caused it. I need laser surgery.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Eye disorders (Diabetic retinopathy complications). Worsening eye disease linked to control.

complaint: So I gave myself the injection on Thursday night before bed. Woke up Friday morning and my lips felt kind of tingly and weird. Looked in the bathroom mirror and my lips were definitely swollen, like noticeably puffed up. And then I noticed I had hives on my chest and neck too. I took some Benadryl right away and kept monitoring myself. The swelling got a bit worse over the next hour and I started to feel like my throat might be tightening up, though I could still breathe okay. My husband wanted to call 911 but I said let's go to the ER instead since I wasn't having trouble breathing yet. At the ER they gave me IV Benadryl and steroids and monitored me for like 4 hours. The swelling gradually went down. The doctor said this was an allergic reaction and I shouldn't take Ozempic anymore. He prescribed me an EpiPen just in case I ever have another reaction to something. Pretty scary honestly.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Hypersensitivity. Rapid-onset angioedema with airway involvement denotes serious allergic reaction.

complaint: Hi, um, I need to report something that's been happening. So I started Ozempic so about you know two  -  months ago, and I've been having these episodes where my heart starts racing. complaint: Hi, um, , I need to report something that's been happening since I started Ozempic. complaint: I'm a new patient just starting on Ozempic and when I got home with my prescription and opened the carton to read through everything before my first dose, I realized the patient information leaflet is completely missing. The carton had the pen and the needle tips but no paperwork whatsoever. This is my first time using this medication so I really needed those instructions. I drove back to the pharmacy and explained the situation to the pharmacist, and she was nice enough to photocopy the instruction leaflet from another box they had in stock so at least I'd have something to reference. The meter said 45 which is way too low. The paramedics came and gave me something to bring my sugar up. The problem is I take insulin in the morning, been doing that for years, but I also started taking this Ozempic shot about two months ago and my doctor never lowered my insulin dose. I think the combination made my blood sugar drop too much. I have a follow-up appointment next week to adjust my medications.

complaint: I had intense stomach pain that felt like a knife twisting in my gut. It went straight through to my back. I was doubled over in agony. complaint: I've noticed that since they increased my dose - I think I'm on 1 mg now - my heart rate has been higher than normal. Happened about a week after the dose increase.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Cardiovascular signs. Sustained HR increase and palpitations post-titration fit CV sign category.

complaint: I have a huge, red, itchy welt on my stomach where I injected the medication. It's hot and painful to the touch. It's been there for four days and isn't getting better. It looks like a giant bug bite. My doctor says it's a localized injection site reaction but told me to watch for signs of infection.

complaint: So, um, this is my second time trying to report this because I wasn't sure if it was related but my doctor said I should definitely document it. I know, TMI, but it's been really bad. I'm only going maybe once a week if I'm lucky, and when I do it's really difficult and uncomfortable. My stomach is constantly bloated and I look like I'm pregnant even though I've actually lost weight overall. I've been taking Miralax every day, drinking tons of water, eating salads with lots of fiber, and it's still a problem. My doctor is suggesting we try a lower dose to see if that helps because apparently this is a pretty common side effect.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Gastrointestinal disorders. Prolonged constipation post-titration aligns with common GI adverse effects.

complaint: I have severe abdominal pain that radiates to my back. I'm vomiting and have a fever. My lipase levels are elevated. The doctor diagnosed me with acute pancreatic inflammation. I'm in the hospital getting fluids and pain medication.

complaint: I inhaled stomach contents stomach contents during a scope. I have pneumonia now. My stomach was full of liquid. The doctor says it delayed emptying.

complaint: I feel my heart skipping beats. It flutters in my chest. My pulse is irregular. The doctor says I'm having PVCs and my heart rate is high. It's uncomfortable and scary.

complaint: I'm reporting what I believe to be diverted or possibly not authentic Ozempic that I unfortunately purchased. I was looking for better prices and found an online seller advertising bulk discounts - offering twelve pens at a significant savings if you bought in quantity. They claimed to ship from Canada to the US, which I thought was legal for personal use. Placed an order and the pens arrived a few weeks later. As soon as I opened the package, I knew something was off. All the labeling is in French only, no English at all. The box design looks similar to Ozempic packaging but the colors and layout are slightly different from what I'm used to. The color scheme doesn't match the FDA-approved packaging I've seen before. I tried looking up the NDC number online and it returns no results in the US database - like the code doesn't exist in our system. My regular pharmacist looked at it and immediately said this is likely diverted product from the Canadian market that's not approved for sale in the US. Different packaging, different regulatory approval, possibly different manufacturing standards or quality oversight. Or it could be not authentic made to look like Canadian product. Either way, she strongly advised not to use it and to report the seller. The medication came from an unauthorized distribution channel and doesn't meet US regulatory requirements. I'm out the money and learned a hard lesson about buying prescription drugs from random online sellers offering bulk discounts.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Counterfeit/Unauthorized source. Foreign-labeled product with unapproved packaging from unauthorized channel indicates diversion or counterfeit.

complaint: The dial made a loud cracking sound when I was turning it, and now it just spins freely without changing the dose numbers. I can't set my 0.5 mg dose because the internal gears must have snapped.

reasoning: Category: Device malfunction. Mechanical breakage of the dial mechanism.

complaint: The constipation is so bad it's causing hemorrhoids and fissures. I'm in pain every time I try to go to the bathroom. I'm using laxatives daily but they barely help. I'm really frustrated because I've wasted a pen, and these are expensive. I like haven't used it because I don't know if it's still good, and I don't want to risk using ineffective medication. I'm documenting this as a product issue report because it's a storage and shipping issue that affects product quality.

complaint: Every time I inject this medication, I get a reaction at the injection site. I've tried different areas - my stomach, my thighs - and it happens regardless of where I inject. The site gets red and swollen and tender. Usually it's about the size of a quarter or maybe a bit bigger. It's also itchy and warm to the touch. The reaction lasts for 3-4 days typically before it starts to fade. I've been doing these injections for about 3 months now so I've had this happen probably 12 times. I mentioned it to my doctor and she examined one of the active reactions. She said it's a localized hypersensitivity reaction but not a dangerous one since it's just at the injection site and I don't have any systemic symptoms. She suggested I try icing the area before and after injection, which has helped a little bit. The medication is working well for my diabetes so I'm willing to put up with the injection site reactions if I have to.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Injection-site reactions. Localized cutaneous reaction at administration site without systemic features.

complaint: There is a piece of metal wire inside the cartridge. It looks like a staple. It's rusting in the liquid. This is dangerous foreign material.

reasoning: Category: Contamination/Foreign matter. Metal contaminant.

complaint: I was scheduled for a gastric sleeve surgery, but they had to abort the procedure after induction. He said my stomach isn't emptying and I need to be off this medication for at least 3 weeks before we try again.

complaint: Okay so, um, let me explain what happened because it's been really rough. I moved up to the 1 mg dose like three weeks ago and at first everything seemed fine. I also couldn't eat because I felt so nauseous, and I was afraid to eat because of the diarrhea. Finally I went to urgent care because I was feeling really out of it. They did blood work and said my kidney function was off - my creatinine was elevated, whatever that means. They gave me two bags of IV fluids and told me I needed to stop the Ozempic and see my regular doctor within a couple days. I did stop it and the diarrhea gradually got better over the next week. My doctor rechecked my kidney function and it's improving but still not back to normal. She said the dehydration from all the GI issues caused my kidneys to not work properly.

reasoning: Category: Renal events (Acute kidney injury). AKI likely precipitated by GI fluid loss; recognized risk with GLP-1 RAs.

complaint: I'm calling about a problem with my like Ozempic pen. So the injection button ... is like completely stuck. Like, I can't depress it at all, no matter how hard I push. I've tried everything - pushing it straight down, twisting it, nothing works. uh It's like it's frozen in place. I can dial the dose fine, the counter works, but I can't actually inject because the button won't move. This is a brand new pen, I just opened it. I'm completely unable to use it. I called my pharmacy and they're sending me a replacement, but I wanted to report this because this is a mechanical failure. If the button doesn't work, people can't use the pen at all. This is a product defect that prevents use of the medication. I'm documenting this as a product issue report because it's a device issue.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Describes device mechanical failure preventing use, a product defect without adverse patient reaction.

complaint: This was really scary. So I've been on Ozempic for about five weeks, and I've been having a lot of nausea and vomiting. It's been ... pretty bad, but I was I mean trying to stick with it because my doctor said the side effects should improve. But last week, I was vomiting really badly for two weeks straight. I couldn't keep anything down, not even water. I got really dehydrated. My blood pressure dropped really low, and I actually passed out. My husband found me on the floor and called 911. The paramedics came and took me to the hospital. I was really dehydrated, my  -  blood  -  pressure was 80 over 50, um which is dangerously low. They gave me IV fluids and kept me overnight. The doctors said the vomiting from Ozempic caused severe dehydration, which led to low blood pressure and fainting. I'm better uh now, but it was really scary. I've stopped the medication  -  because I can't deal with this level of side effects. I think this needs to be reported because it was a serious complication.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Describes serious complications (dehydration, hypotension, syncope) from medication adverse effects requiring emergency care.

complaint: I suspect these pens are not authentic. The packaging looks low quality and the colors are off. The QR code on the side doesn't scan. The price was too good to be true.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Counterfeit/Unauthorized source. Visual discrepancies and scan failure indicating counterfeit.

complaint: Something is definitely wrong with this pen and I'm concerned the medication might be diluted or has incorrect concentration. Yesterday was my injection day, so I dialed up my usual 0.5 mg dose on the pen and did the injection. But it felt different than normal - the injection was over really quickly, much faster than usual, and it felt too easy, like there wasn't the usual resistance. At first I thought maybe I just imagined it, but then over the next 24 hours I didn't feel any of the usual effects of the medication. No appetite suppression, no GI effects, nothing. Like I hadn't taken anything at all. So I ended up dialing another 0.5 mg dose and taking it again, and same thing - too quick, too easy, no effect. By the end of the day I had dialed and injected the 0.5 mg dose three times total, thinking maybe it wasn't delivering properly or I was doing something wrong. But I'm experienced with this medication, I know how it should feel and work. My concern is that this particular pen might have diluted medication or incorrect concentration. Like maybe the active ingredient amount is lower than it should be. Otherwise why would I feel absolutely nothing after three doses when one dose normally has a clear effect? I kept the pen and brought it to the pharmacy. They're sending it to the manufacturer for potency testing because if the concentration is wrong in this lot, that's a serious quality control and safety issue affecting dosing accuracy.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Potency/Assay defect. Apparent lack of expected pharmacological effect combined with unusual delivery suggests potency issue.

complaint: There are multiple issues with the packaging integrity of the pen I just received that make me question whether it's safe to use. First, the transparent plastic shrink wrap or cellophane wrapper that's supposed to be tightly sealed around the outer carton was really loose and baggy. I was able to easily slide it off without tearing anything or breaking any seal - it just slipped right off. That wrapper is supposed to be tamper-evident, so if it comes off that easily, how do I know someone hasn't already opened it? Then I opened the carton and looked at the internal blister seal - you know, that foil or plastic seal that covers the pen inside the tray. That seal was partially open at one corner. Like it had been peeled back or never fully sealed in the first place. You could actually see the edge of the pen through the gap in the seal. Between the loose outer wrapper and the compromised inner seal, the product integrity is really questionable. There's no way to be certain that this pen hasn't been tampered with, contaminated, or exposed to conditions it shouldn't have been. This is an injectable medication - sterility and integrity are absolutely critical. I took it back to the pharmacy immediately and they agreed the packaging failures are unacceptable. They documented it thoroughly, quarantined all the pens from that same lot, and are reporting it to their quality department. They gave me a replacement from a completely different lot with proper intact seals.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Packaging defect. Multiple compromised seals indicate packaging integrity failure affecting sterility assurance.

complaint: Um, so this is kind of scary but I've been having these episodes where I get really dizzy and start sweating a lot. The first time it happened I was at work and had to sit down because I thought I was going to pass out. My coworker who has diabetes suggested I check my blood sugar, so I went to the nurse's office and they tested it - it was 54! I also take that glipizide pill in the morning along with the Ozempic. Had to drink some orange juice to feel better. This has happened like three times now, always on days when I take both medications.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Hypoglycemia. Low glucose with symptoms and a sulfonylurea co-med increases hypoglycemia risk.

complaint: I've been having severe pain in my upper right abdomen, mostly after eating fatty meals. It's a sharp, cramping pain that doubles me over. Last night it was so bad I went to the ER. An ultrasound showed my gallbladder is full of stones and the wall is thickened. The surgeon said I have acute gallbladder inflammation and need my gallbladder out. He mentioned that rapid weight loss can cause biliary stones, and I've lost about 35 pounds in the last 4 months on this medication. It's a painful price to pay for the weight loss.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Hepatobiliary (gallbladder) disease. Acute cholecystitis and cholelithiasis associated with rapid weight loss.

complaint: The delivery truck had no AC. The box was scorching hot. The medication is cooked. It needs to be refrigerated.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Storage/Temperature excursion. Heat damage during transport.

complaint: The pen looks fake. The blue is the wrong shade. The plastic feels cheap. The label is crooked. It's a not authentic.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Counterfeit/Unauthorized source. Visual counterfeit indicators.

complaint: Okay so I need to talk about what happened with my injection site this week because it really freaked me out. I do my injections in my thigh, alternating legs each week. This time I injected into my left thigh on Wednesday morning and by that afternoon the spot was really red and swollen. Like way more than usual - it was probably the size of a golf ball, maybe bigger? And it was hot to the touch and painful. I was worried it might be infected so I sent a picture to my doctor through the patient portal. She had me come in the next day to check it out. She said it didn't look infected, just a significant local reaction to the medication. She cleaned the area, put some hydrocortisone cream on it, and told me to apply cold compresses. It took almost a week to fully resolve. She said if it happens again we might need to consider a different medication.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Injection-site reactions. Localized cutaneous reaction at administration site without systemic features.

complaint: I'm calling about something that's really upsetting me. So I've been on Ozempic for about three months, and I've lost about twenty-five pounds, actually which is great. But you know about a month ago, I started uh noticing that my hair was falling out. Like, a lot. I'm losing handfuls of hair in the shower, it's coming out when I brush it, it's everywhere. I went to my doctor and she said it's telogen effluvium, which is hair loss that can happen after stress or major changes to your uh body. She thinks it's related to the rapid weight loss from the Ozempic. So it's not directly from the medication itself, but from the weight loss the medication causes. ... I'm really upset because I'm losing my hair, and it's um affecting my self-esteem. I don't know if I should , stop the medication, but my blood sugar is so much better. This is really affecting my quality of life. I think this needs to be documented because even though it's indirect, it's a significant problem.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Reports adverse effect (alopecia) indirectly related to medication-induced rapid weight loss, affecting patient quality of life.

complaint: When I try to press the injection button, it feels like there's something blocking it internally. It takes an incredible amount of force to get it to budge, and even then, it only moves a tiny bit before getting stuck again. I'm afraid I'm not getting the full dose because the mechanism just isn't advancing the plunger correctly.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Device malfunction. Mechanical resistance in the injection button.

complaint: The dose dial is stuck between numbers. It won't click into place. I can't select the correct dose.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Category: Device malfunction. Dose selector misalignment.

complaint: I have biliary stones. The pain is in my right side. I need surgery. The doctor says the weight loss caused it. I'm scheduled for a cholecystectomy.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Hepatobiliary (gallbladder) disease. Weight-loss induced gallstones.

complaint: I'm calling about a major error I found. So I got my Ozempic pen, and when I opened the box, I looked at the user manual that came with it. But the manual is for a completely different product - it's for Victoza, which is also made by Novo Nordisk, but it's a different medication. The instructions are completely wrong. They're talking about a different pen, different , dosing, everything is wrong. This is a serious packaging so error. If someone uses the wrong instructions, they could use the pen incorrectly, which could be dangerous. I called my pharmacy and they're I mean sending me the correct manual, but I wanted to report this because ... this is a major error. The product should have the correct instructions. This is a regulatory compliance issue - the wrong instructions could lead to medication errors.
label: Product Complaint
reasoning: Describes serious labeling/packaging error with incorrect product instructions, a regulatory compliance issue.

complaint: Patient presented for outpatient bronchoscopy for evaluation of persistent cough. Pre-procedure assessment completed, patient confirmed adherence to NPO guidelines (nothing to eat or drink after midnight, procedure at 11 AM). During conscious sedation with midazolam and fentanyl, patient suddenly vomited and inhaled stomach contents before protective reflexes could be engaged. Procedure immediately halted, patient placed in Trendelenburg position, airway suctioned. Emergently intubated for airway protection. Therapeutic bronchoscopy performed showing significant volume of gastric contents throughout bronchial tree requiring extensive suctioning. Patient transferred to ICU intubated for continued airway management and monitoring. Chest imaging consistent with bilateral inhaled stomach contents. Developed severe inhaled stomach contents pneumonitis requiring mechanical ventilation for 48 hours. Comprehensive medication review revealed patient on semaglutide for 5 months. Pulmonology and anesthesiology teams emphasize need for extended GLP-1 agonist washout period (minimum 2 weeks) before any sedated procedure given profound effect on gastric emptying.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Peri-procedural aspiration risk. Aspiration event in context of delayed gastric emptying associated with GLP-1 RAs.

complaint: I vomit undigested food almost every day. I feel nauseous from the moment I wake up until I go to sleep. I've lost my appetite completely. My doctor says my stomach paralysis is severe based on the emptying study. I'm malnourished and weak. We stopped the drug two weeks ago but the symptoms are resolving very slowly.
label: Adverse Event
reasoning: Category: Gastrointestinal disorders (Gastroparesis). Severe, persistent gastroparesis symptoms leading to malnutrition.
